title: Jan Kameník
text:
Jan Kameník (born 25 January 1982) is a Czech <a href="association%20football">football</a> manager who manages <a href="FC%20Vyso%C4%8Dina%20Jihlava">FC Vysočina Jihlava</a>.
Club career.
In his youth years, Kameník featured for his local <a href="Otrokovice">Otrokovice</a>-based <a href="SK%20Ba%C5%A5ov%201930">Baťov 1930</a> and had a two year loan in <a href="SK%20Sigma%20Olomouc">Sigma Olomouc</a>. He spent his senior career in lower amateur tiers of <a href="Czech%20Republic%20football%20league%20system">Czech league system</a>, with his peak at a <a href="Czech%20Fourth%20Division">then-fourth division</a> side TJ FS Napajedla. He often played recreational football for amateur sides. In early 2000s, he played in lower divisions of Austrian football.
Managerial career.
Youth teams.
Kameník began his managerial career with <a href="1.%20FC%20Slov%C3%A1cko">Slovácko</a>, where he spent 8 years with the youth squads. His tenure culminated by managing the U19 squad. While at Slovácko, Kameník attained his <a href="UEFA%20Pro%20Licence">UEFA Pro Licence</a>. Here he gained notoriety as a specialist in managing the youth squads.
He later relocated to serve as an authority within a regional football academy based ran by <a href="Football%20Association%20of%20the%20Czech%20Republic">FAČR</a> in <a href="Jihlava">Jihlava</a>. While at the academy, Kameník was invited to coach the U19 squad at local <a href="FC%20Vyso%C4%8Dina%20Jihlava">Vysočina Jihlava</a>. He stayed with the site for half-year.
Assistant in Jihlava.
When the former assistant manager at <a href="FC%20Vyso%C4%8Dina%20Jihlava">Vysočina Jihlava</a>, <a href="Michal%20Hipp">Michal Hipp</a> departed from the club, <a href="Michal%20B%C3%ADlek">Michal Bílek</a> had invited Kameník to serve as his assistant. Kameník became the assistant in January 2017 but the duo was relieved of their duties by April, following a series of dissatisfactory results. He returned to the U19 squad briefly, but departed the club entirely by June.
Fastav Zlín.
Ahead of the <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20Czech%20First%20League">2017–18</a> season, Kameník became the assistant of <a href="Bohumil%20P%C3%A1n%C3%ADk">Bohumil Páník</a> at <a href="FC%20Fastav%20Zl%C3%ADn">Fastav Zlín</a>. With Páník and his other assistant Jan Somberg, Kameník co-coached Zlín in the <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%20group%20stage">group stage</a> of the UEFA Europa League and led them to victory at a pre-season <a href="Czechoslovak%20Supercup">Czechoslovak Supercup</a>. Páník was replaced by <a href="Vlastimil%20Petr%C5%BEela">Vlastimil Petržela</a> in March 2018, after three years at the club. Kameník continued to serve as an assistant under Petržela, who remained with the club until the end of the season and departed after few minor controversies. Zlín narrowly avoided relegation that season.
At the start of <a href="2018%E2%80%9319%20Czech%20First%20League">2018–19 season</a>, Kameník had reunited with Michal Bílek who was named <a href="FC%20Fastav%20Zl%C3%ADn">Zlín's</a> new manager. The reunited duo, along with club's sporting director <a href="Zden%C4%9Bk%20Grygera">Zdeněk Grygera</a>, began to pursue a play in a 3-5-2 formation. Despite initial success, the former <a href="Czech%20Republic%20national%20football%20team">Czech national team</a> Bílek departed the club in winter, when he was named the manager of <a href="Kazakhstan%20national%20football%20team">Kazakhstan</a>. Bílek was replaced by <a href="Slovakia">Slovak</a> manager <a href="Roman%20Pivarn%C3%ADk">Roman Pivarník</a>, who kept Kameník as his assistant. Pivarník's side, however, recorded mere 9 points in eleven fixtures and failed to score in seven of those. Consequently, Pivarník was let go in April and Kameník took over as a manager of a senior team for the first time in his career, although merely on a caretaker basis, until the end of the season. Kameník had led the team during the Europa League play-offs to determine the final participant from the <a href="Czech%20Republic">Czech Republic</a>. Fastav advanced through <a href="SK%20Sigma%20Olomouc">Sigma Olomouc</a> in the quarter-finals by the <a href="away%20goals%20rule">away goals rule</a> but was knocked out in the semi-finals by <a href="FK%20Mlad%C3%A1%20Boleslav">Mladá Boleslav</a>, who won the ultimate spot. He concluded his brief spell with a tally of two wins and two defeats.
Ahead of the <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20Czech%20First%20League">2019–20 season</a>, Kameník was again degraded to a role of an assistant manager, this time serving under <a href="Josef%20Csapl%C3%A1r">Josef Csaplár</a>. Csaplár was too let go within half-year as, according to <a href="Zden%C4%9Bk%20Grygera">Grygera</a>, he lacked the results, despite attracting a number of his former players. This time, however Kameník was promoted to a role of a manager by Grygera, in hopes of having a local manager improve the results, becoming league' youngest manager. Petr Slončík was named Kameník's assistant, after managing <a href="FC%20TVD%20Slavi%C4%8D%C3%ADn">TVD Slavičín</a>. Kameník's managerial spell concluded in March 2020. His spell saw three wins and three draws in league fixtures and a <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20Czech%20Cup">MOL Cup</a> knock-out in Round of 16 by <a href="FK%20Mlad%C3%A1%20Boleslav">Mladá Boleslav</a>. The results saw Zlín drop to a relegation zone and Kameník was subsequently replaced by the returning <a href="Bohumil%20P%C3%A1n%C3%ADk">Bohumil Páník</a>.
FC Strání.
In September 2020, Kameník signed a contract with <a href="Czech%20Fourth%20Division">Fourth Division</a> side . At Strání, he re-united with numerous players from nearby <a href="Uhersk%C3%A9%20Hradi%C5%A1t%C4%9B">Uherské Hradiště</a>-based <a href="1.%20FC%20Slov%C3%A1cko">Slovácko</a>. He led the team in five matches, with two wins and a draw.
FK Pohronie.
In mid-October, Kameník was announced as a new manager of <a href="FK%20Pohronie">Pohronie</a>, based in <a href="%C5%BDiar%20nad%20Hronom">Žiar nad Hronom</a>, <a href="Slovakia">Slovakia</a>. Pohronie avoided relegation in their novice top-division <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20Slovak%20First%20Football%20League">season</a> under <a href="Mikul%C3%A1%C5%A1%20Radv%C3%A1nyi">Mikuláš Radványi</a>, who kicked off the <a href="2020%E2%80%9321%20Slovak%20First%20Football%20League">2020–21 season</a> as well. In early October, however, Pohronie had undergone a minor personal crisis: <a href="Captain%20%28association%20football%29">ex-captain</a> <a href="Luk%C3%A1%C5%A1%20Pelegr%C3%ADni">Lukáš Pelegríni</a>, local striker <a href="Patrik%20Abrah%C3%A1m">Patrik Abrahám</a>, as well as <a href="Canada">Canadian</a> pre-season arrival Ryan Lindsay. After these departures, sporting director <a href="Miroslav%20Filipko">Miroslav Filipko</a> and manager <a href="Mikul%C3%A1%C5%A1%20Radv%C3%A1nyi">Mikuláš Radványi</a> were both subsequently released from the club. Kameník was brought in as a prospective coach with professional recommendations and marked a beginning of an internal transformation of the club.
Kameník had his managerial debut with <a href="FK%20Pohronie">Pohronie</a> on 17 October 2020 in a fixture against <a href="AS%20Tren%C4%8D%C3%ADn">AS Trenčín</a>, at <a href="%C5%A0tadi%C3%B3n%20pod%20Dub%C5%88om">pod Dubňom</a>, in a 1–1 tie. Despite being one-down at half time <a href="James%20Weir%20%28footballer%29">James Weir</a> equalised with a second-half header. Immediately in the first match, Kameník restructured Pohronie to play in his preferred 3-5-2 <a href="Formation%20%28association%20football%29">formation</a>, dropping the previously used 4-3-3.
